title: 1.0 out of 5 stars Allergic reaction, weak app, connectivity issues
author: Mack
content: Edit: added more at the endIf you had an allergic reaction to Samsung Buds 2 or their other earbuds, you'll react to these as well. I wore the Rail ANC for less than one afternoon and by dinner my ears were already reacting with liquid discharge. This morning at 4am I had one ear almost totally crusted over and still leaking while the other was leaking but less crusted. I've had this reaction before and I suspect it's the material used for the inserts. Also, the little logo they put on them didn't help either. Anything that causes friction in the ear canal is a stupid idea. I got these for a trip I'm taking on a plane across country and I'm kinda screwed now because I can't return them in time to get something else. My old wired headphones from when I bought my Samsung pgone don't react, so I took those ear inserts and luckily they fit, so I through them on. Once my ears stop reacting and chill out, I'll see if that fixes the issue in time for my trip.As far as function goes, the headphones are okay at best. They can get plenty loud to the point that ANC or their Stay Aware pass through mode mean nothing. It's nice to know I can listen at lower volumes like I prefer and still have ambient noise be mostly audible or have anc keep things subdued. But subdued is the best they give and mostly audible ambient noise is about as much as you can expect. These aren't stellar at either. Doable, but not something I'd laude about.They sound pretty good for what they are. Not sure if I'd say they're $100 headphone quality or value, allergies aside, but they don't sound awful by any means. Music was clear and had some rumble. I used the sound personalization and it was easy enough to get decent sound. There a bass boost, general music and podcast sound setting with a customizable equalizer in the app as well.The buttons on the side are touch activated and finicky. I tend to tap fast and expect fast responses, but these prefer a more methodical pace. The sweetspot for where to touch is also funky, but I started getting it after a few hours. Also, the audio queues are clear enough, but an option to remove them would make things feel faster. Also, if they're not in my ear, I wish touch capacity stopped. Plenty of time I took one out and accidentally started changing tracks, changing volume and activating pairing mode.I remapped all the touch responses and even changed what ear did what. One tap on either paused, double tap on left was volume down, on right it's volume up. Three taps left was previous track and same on the right was skip ahead. Long press in either toggles ANC on/off and pass through audio. I appreciate customization like that.For what stands out as good, I'd say it's the voice prompts. Much quicker to respond than on my phone or watch and that's kinda sad because it's the feature I'll probably never use and cared rhe least about, but seemed so much better than my phones inbuilt assistant that Samsung spent so much time, effort and money on to develop (rip bixby). If you like using voice commands, that's gonna go great, although the "take photo" command doesn't work with my Samsung's camera app. Again, not something I was after anyways.One of my favorite features was the built-in tile function for finding them if I lose one or both. The tile app isn't super intuitive, but I mostly figured it out and stumbled my way into it connecting both buds. It creates a tone I can hear when the room in my apartment is silent and has a directional sensor to let me know if I'm getting hotter or colder. Granted, it's not terribly responsive, sensitive or consistent, but if I moved slowly through a room, I bet between the proximity sensor and sound I'd probably find one if I lost one. It's a nice feature to have where I'd otherwise be totally screwed, so I'll take a win where I can with these.I got these on pre-order. When they were scheduled to release after 2 weeks, they ended up coming 10 days earlier or less. It seems weird i had to pre-order when people said they were already at Walmart for a couple weeks, but whatever.I'll update after my ears recover and try them using the non-reactive ear inserts from my old wired heaphones and see if they don't react again. I was furious about my Galaxy Buds 2 causing this reaction, but my wired stuff and my LG Tone Platinums never caused an issue. If it weren't summer and the LG Tone Platinums weren't makeing my neck hot, I might never have bothered looking at this style Bluetooth buds again. But it's a trip to a Nevada training center after the hottest july month on record in human history with averages around 110 in the area I'll be. I thought I'd take a chance on mild comfort. I'm hoping I didn't waste my money now that almost out of time.EDIT: It's been a few days so I'll add more input. Battery is pretty good, but it's not enough to bump a star.The app Skullcandy IQ is awful. It's what controls your key presses. The problem is the app is always on, but loses connection and resets all your programmed key presses. I end up having to reset them every day when they eventually connect poorly. The app logo constantly in my phones notification bar isn't necessary or tell me any input about my headphones. If it at least told me battery levels or connection status, maybe I wouldn't be so annoyed, but this just ISN'T ready for prime time.Also, the ear inserts are what caused the allergic reaction. They jerryrigged replacements I found by chance from a totally different set of wired buds from an old phone work well enough, but I shouldn't have to find my own replacements. At least having an option for different inserts that are non-reactive would be beneficial like memory foam or whatever. Again, Samsung Buds 2 had this EXACT issue and replacing inserts with an aftermarket set was the only solution. For a list of symptoms, it's pretty unmistakable: liquid discharge, discolored mucousal discharge in ear, weeping ear, flaking and scaly skim that seems to build up and shed, pain itching, inflammation, basically a large skin irritation in your ear canal that, if unmanaged, becomes a severe ear infection. Samsung got sued for it and has been paying out for their affected customers. Skullcandy is headed the same way with these unless they have a hypoallergenic replacement in the wing.If the connectivity issue wasn't so bad and not saving my preset remapped button setting wasn't so annoying, perhaps I would add a star or two, but this isn't ready for release and I'm probably returning after giving another day or two. Really sucks I'm screwed out of my trip for headphones, but I'm not gonna struggle with a new set of buds I paid good money for. I'll just go back to wired at this point.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 6, 2023

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Immediate issues
author: xjarius
content: I have long been a fan of Skullcandy headphones and earbuds, at least 10 - 15 years. The earbuds were always decent and sturdy, even if you got cheaper ones.My last pair of true wireless earbuds were the Skullcandy Indy earbuds, and I was so sorry to see these were no longer being made.But I was looking forward to the Rail ANC earbuds. First, ANC! Second, a decent IPX4. Third, great battery life. Plus, they cost more, so they must be higher quality, right? So I splurged a little on June 28, 2024. These earbuds sound pretty good. I can tell only a minor difference when the ANC is on and when it's off. The passthrough mode is okay, maybe about as good as the Indy's. The battery life was amazing. That's right. Was. We'll get to that. I loved using the app SkullIQ, where you can customize control settings. I was able to change what the number of taps on the sensor does. Super cool!My list of gripes as of 8/23/2024.First of all, how did my right earbud stop working within the first month? There's a sound when you press the sensor. Within 2 weeks, it started randomly making the sensor pressing sound. Then it started saying Pairing... pairing... as if I was doing long single presses. Then it started skipping to the next track(triple press) and trying to start Spotify* (double press). Within the first month it just wouldn't power on at all. I tried all the tricks and worked with Skullcandy support to no avail. They suggested I submit a warranty claim.*Sidenote: how does it fail to open Spotify whether I'm listening to Spotify or not?).Sometimes they will connect to my phone even thought they are in their case and should be off. My Indy's would do this, too, but it took at least a year or two before that started. This started within the first two months.Every once in a while they wont even connect and you will have to go to settings, forget device, then pair them to your phone again. This is what Skullcandy support had me try to fix the right earbud. Occasionally I need to do this on the left earbud as well. Well if you do this, you have to customize the SkullIQ app again.The case is cheap. My Indy's case was solid and sturdy. It had a few LEDs to indicate how much battery life was left in the case. This new one is flimsy with one light that shows you if the battery is being charged or not.Lastly, the Indy's stayed in my ears much better than the Rail's do. So I'm constantly needing to readjust them in my ears. With a name like Rail, I figured it was made for an active lifestyle. I wash windows for a living, but these things don't stay in my ears too well.As of today, they are in the mail headed to San Diego for the warranty claim. Hopefully, I get a somewhat better product when it's returned.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 23, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars These buds murder AirPods Pro 2
author: Joshua Busby
content: Tl;dr - Here‚Äôs what you probably came here to find out:- Sound quality is phenomenal. Deep bass and rich crystal clear highs. Hands down better than AirPods Pro 2, and significantly so imo.- Battery life is the longest I‚Äôve ever experienced, once again shaming Apple.- Noise cancelling is great. For this, I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs equal to AirPods Pro 2, if not slightly better.- They fit very snugly in my ears and don‚Äôt fall out with movement. They come with three pairs of ear tips, each a different size.- Very good construction and premium feel. They also look really good.- The charging case can either be charged with a type-C wire, or on any wireless charger by laying them down on the charging pad.- The Skullcandy IQ app is actually useful with features such as custom EQ, voice control configuration, ANC controls, etc.Long version:Borrowed my Wife‚Äôs AirPods Pro 2 off and on for a week before deciding to give these a go as they were 50% off, and as someone who listens to metal and hard rock, these things absolutely murder Apple‚Äôs flagship buds. As far as sound quality and loudness, going from the AirPods Pro 2 to these was like going from ramen noodles to premium ribeye. The bass is right where it should be, and the treble is crystal clear and clean. Loud is an understatement. I use Spotify Premium and am happy with the EQ within that app, but the EQ within the Skullcandy app is really great as well. These are made well and feel great. Battery is roughly 6-7 hours, so really great. They fit great, are very comfortable, and don‚Äôt fall out with movement. All in all, these buds are amazing. Apple can‚Äôt compete.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Unfortunately, not a great purchase‚Ä¶ but I am keeping them.
author: Kyle H.
content: I had skull candy headphones as a kid, and loved them. Granted, this is back when headphones still physically plugged into a device or phone. So when I saw these I was super excited. Unfortunately, they ended up being the LEAST enjoyable earbud I have purchased, yet. Before you read further, it is worth noting that a lot of people are super satisfied with these earbuds, so it is extremely likely that this is more about my user preferences not matching with the specs of the item. That being said, the following are the agitations and the positives I‚Äôve experienced since using them:THE CONS:‚Ä¢ The earbuds regularly don‚Äôt sync with my phone & I am prompted at least 3x a week to ‚Äúforget‚Äù the earbuds and then go through the pairing process again. Not a huge problem, but a mild inconvenience made worse by the regularity in which it happens.‚Ä¢ The earbuds fall out of my ears from my jaw moving, which happens often, because my jaw moves when I talk on the phone.‚Ä¢ The earbuds require an app to be downloaded to my phone, in order to customize each button sequence to the desired function (I.e. answer phone, play music, skip forward, etc.). The frustration I have with this is that the earbuds can answer a phone call with a tap, but they cannot end the call with a tap. So, in order to hang up, I have to use my phone screen (or wait for the person I‚Äôm talking with to hang up).‚Ä¢ The earbuds verbalize information about the device, each time you put them in your ear. I can see how some people might prefer this, but I prefer just a simple one or two note ‚Äúchime‚Äù to let me know the earbud is connected to the device. These earbuds state the following, each time I put them in: *chime*‚Ä¶ pause‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúBattery at __%‚Äù‚Ä¶ pause‚Ä¶ ‚Äúconnected‚Äù. This will happen, even if you‚Äôre listening to music or are actively talking on the phone & you swap earbuds. Again, not a huge problem, but a frequent nuisance.THE PROS:Now, despite these gripes, I will say that the sound quality of both phone calls and music are REALLY good (for the price of the earbud). Moreover, I have used AirPods, Beats Pro, and JBL earbuds‚Ä¶ and I have had a few people tell me that the sound quality of my voice for them (when on the phone) is noticeably better. I did not ask these people before hand, they voiced it on their own accord. One person even said ‚Äúdid you get new headphones?! I can hear you so much better now!‚Äù. For these reasons, despite my many personal gripes, I am keeping the headphones. But buyer beware, they are definitely frustrating at times.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Amazing sound quality, awkward fit

content: I purchased these in November 2023 and have been using them regularly for the past few months. The sound quality is amazing, I absolutely adore the ‚Äúpersonal sound‚Äù through the app it uses. It connects really easily, barely a hassle. I like the added features, like how it can connect to Spotify instantly and play from the earbuds, or how it can detect whether or not you‚Äôre listening to an audiobook/podcast and adjust volumes accordingly. I also like the noise cancelling, it has a slider where you can adjust how much or how little you‚Äôd want. Overall, when it comes to the sound, it knocks it out of the ballpark.Though, one of my only gripes with it is the fit. It wasn‚Äôt built for movement. Even walking around with it indoors, it tends to pop out unless I continually push it back in. I‚Äôve tried the multiple ear tips provided, but it doesn‚Äôt seem to help much. The other gripe I have with it is the controls, and how sensitive it is. Remember how I mentioned I have to continually push it back in? Well, 9/10 times I‚Äôll accidentally pause the song, skip, or start pairing mode. The touch controls are nice, but I wish it wasn‚Äôt as sensitive, because the slightest poke sends it into a frenzy.Overall, it‚Äôs amazing if you‚Äôre just using it at home, stationary. The sound and battery life is phenomenal. If you plan to use it on the go, walking to and from places, etc. I‚Äôd advise to go elsewhere.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Disappointing
author: Bandito
content: I am a big fan of the SC line of ear buds. Let's get that out of the way. I own a set of Grind and Push Active, currently, and the case for the Push stopped charging, which is why I am here.I had really high hopes for these and was really let down. I purchased a set (XT) from Walmart and they sounded terrible. I returned them and saw these on sale and got them, thinking they might be different. The Walmart set was tagged with the 'XT' qualifier, so I didn't know if there were different components used in them.There aren't.1. I feel like I have average sized hands for a dude, so I don't know why I seem to fumble with getting the buds out and into the case. And when I say fumble, I'm talking about the kind of fumble that causes them to fall down a storm drain 10 feet away. I have had to hunt them down because they shot across the room when getting them out. I don't do that with my other sets. I feel like its my technique, but I dont know what the right one is...2. Touch Sensitivity is off the charts. I cannot turn up the volume, turn on ANC or anything else without accidentally pausing what I am listening to, EVERY SINGLE TIME. If you want to take one out to talk to someone, don't hold it in your hand. Now my boss knows I listen to Hailee Steinfeld, and SkullCandy is to blame. 100%. Thanks... I stopped using this feature, I lost patience and went back to doing everything on my phone. This may be a "give it time" thing or maybe making pause/play three taps is the answer.3. The sound. It's kinda bad... especially when you get up in volume. Even at about 75% I can hear distortion and they're no louder than my other sets at 75%. This is why I returned the XT to Walmart, because of this distortion. I do not have this issue with the Grind or Push Active, even at 100%.I don't know what happened.The positives:1. The announcement is toned down and less obtrusive. So if someone calls and I want to put them in, I dont have to pause my convo for 45 seconds. I can hear over it enough now to understand what's being said.2. The bass on them is really f'in nice, which is what I wanted when I bought these. I think this is the trade-off with distortion though, which is a major bummer. I will say that when these things get rockin with a nice bass track that doesn't distort, they can wiggle themselves right out of your ear. All you have to do is push them back in...pause...

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Full-Bodied Sound ... For One
author: Josh Doncevic
content: Bought these during Amazon's Black Friday sale with the express purpose of listening to music at work. Up until today (3/5/2024), when this review is being written, ownership has been fantastic. The Rail ANC earbuds performed effortlessly and are light-years ahead of my previous earbuds from Gravastar. However, one earbud, the left specifically, has ceased to emit any sound. Its touch and ANC features still operate, but there is zero sound emitted through the speaker. This is the first time an earbud or similar device has done this in my experience, and while I know nothing is perfect forever, but I am wondering how it happened. I have my volume set to its lowest setting and do not drop, abuse, or otherwise mistreat the device. When not in use, both earbuds are stored in the charging case. I should also add that I did attempt to pair the earbuds as if for the first time and the left earbud still refused to emit any sound. A disappointment to an otherwise fantastic product.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great For The Price!
author: Jared Morgan
content: The Skullcandy RAIL's offer a mix of impressive features but still has a few limitations. The Bluetooth connectivity is exceptional, ensuring a seamless pairing process, stable connection, and quick reconnection. The device excels in battery performance, boasting extended life and rapid charging capabilities. However, it falls short for gaming enthusiasts due to noticeable latency issues, impacting the overall gaming experience. Additionally, it's worth noting that the Skullcandy RAIL's do not have in-ear detection. Despite these limitations, the Skullcandy RAIL remains a strong contender for those prioritizing top-notch audio in their daily activities. What makes it even more appealing is that it offers these features at a great value for the money.

content: Normally my reviews are very short and to the point however this one's going to be a little bit longer. I didn't think that these would actually be worth it but in fact they are. There are extremely many features that are missing on very expensive earbuds. And I'm talking the big brands...First I'll tell you that when you do set up with the app a hearing test it actually does work it helps greatly especially if ones hearing isn't what it used to be. Secondly, as with most, you can set your equalizer to your own personal settings if you want to. The sound, or music, actually doesn't sound awful again I was a bit surprised. Now another thing that is usually a problem for me just keeping my buds in my ears at all times. Well please actually stay in perfectly and they don't hurt one bit and that's using them for at least 9 hours in a row without taking them out. The battery life as far as I know it looks like it might be pretty good unfortunately I haven't given it enough time to judge that but by the usage I have had with the buds they seem to hold up relatively well with ambient on. Basically I'm very satisfied with these I will keep them and hope that they do keep them updated as they should when needed.Now one con is the app is a pain in the butt. It has to always know you're nearby settings it always ask you to have Bluetooth on, which is already on and the buds are already connected before you get into the app. I don't get that one maybe they'll fix it and the other which is unfortunately the case. The case is a bit flimsy and when you want to try to keep the lid open it keeps falling down so I think that that was a architectural design flaw other than that they're definitely worth it I'll get over the case problem all I have to say is if you want them you'll be happy with them. Used with an Android device.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Definitely worth the money.

content: Are they comparable to some of the top brands? If you consider price, they may be better. My previous buds include Bose and Samsung so this is the basis for my comparison. Audio is more than acceptable; especially is you use the Skull IQ app to customize the sound as well as the included hearing test portion of the app to create a personalized profile. For those that suggest there is not enough bass, I recommend using the app to customize the sound and make sure that the buds are tightly fitted. I would buy them again for the price I paid (not sure why but my price was 49.88 new). Might shop harder at the $89 current price.

title: 1.0 out of 5 stars Allergic reaction, weak app, connectivity issues
author: Mack
content: Edit: added more at the endIf you had an allergic reaction to Samsung Buds 2 or their other earbuds, you'll react to these as well. I wore the Rail ANC for less than one afternoon and by dinner my ears were already reacting with liquid discharge. This morning at 4am I had one ear almost totally crusted over and still leaking while the other was leaking but less crusted. I've had this reaction before and I suspect it's the material used for the inserts. Also, the little logo they put on them didn't help either. Anything that causes friction in the ear canal is a stupid idea. I got these for a trip I'm taking on a plane across country and I'm kinda screwed now because I can't return them in time to get something else. My old wired headphones from when I bought my Samsung pgone don't react, so I took those ear inserts and luckily they fit, so I through them on. Once my ears stop reacting and chill out, I'll see if that fixes the issue in time for my trip.As far as function goes, the headphones are okay at best. They can get plenty loud to the point that ANC or their Stay Aware pass through mode mean nothing. It's nice to know I can listen at lower volumes like I prefer and still have ambient noise be mostly audible or have anc keep things subdued. But subdued is the best they give and mostly audible ambient noise is about as much as you can expect. These aren't stellar at either. Doable, but not something I'd laude about.They sound pretty good for what they are. Not sure if I'd say they're $100 headphone quality or value, allergies aside, but they don't sound awful by any means. Music was clear and had some rumble. I used the sound personalization and it was easy enough to get decent sound. There a bass boost, general music and podcast sound setting with a customizable equalizer in the app as well.The buttons on the side are touch activated and finicky. I tend to tap fast and expect fast responses, but these prefer a more methodical pace. The sweetspot for where to touch is also funky, but I started getting it after a few hours. Also, the audio queues are clear enough, but an option to remove them would make things feel faster. Also, if they're not in my ear, I wish touch capacity stopped. Plenty of time I took one out and accidentally started changing tracks, changing volume and activating pairing mode.I remapped all the touch responses and even changed what ear did what. One tap on either paused, double tap on left was volume down, on right it's volume up. Three taps left was previous track and same on the right was skip ahead. Long press in either toggles ANC on/off and pass through audio. I appreciate customization like that.For what stands out as good, I'd say it's the voice prompts. Much quicker to respond than on my phone or watch and that's kinda sad because it's the feature I'll probably never use and cared rhe least about, but seemed so much better than my phones inbuilt assistant that Samsung spent so much time, effort and money on to develop (rip bixby). If you like using voice commands, that's gonna go great, although the "take photo" command doesn't work with my Samsung's camera app. Again, not something I was after anyways.One of my favorite features was the built-in tile function for finding them if I lose one or both. The tile app isn't super intuitive, but I mostly figured it out and stumbled my way into it connecting both buds. It creates a tone I can hear when the room in my apartment is silent and has a directional sensor to let me know if I'm getting hotter or colder. Granted, it's not terribly responsive, sensitive or consistent, but if I moved slowly through a room, I bet between the proximity sensor and sound I'd probably find one if I lost one. It's a nice feature to have where I'd otherwise be totally screwed, so I'll take a win where I can with these.I got these on pre-order. When they were scheduled to release after 2 weeks, they ended up coming 10 days earlier or less. It seems weird i had to pre-order when people said they were already at Walmart for a couple weeks, but whatever.I'll update after my ears recover and try them using the non-reactive ear inserts from my old wired heaphones and see if they don't react again. I was furious about my Galaxy Buds 2 causing this reaction, but my wired stuff and my LG Tone Platinums never caused an issue. If it weren't summer and the LG Tone Platinums weren't makeing my neck hot, I might never have bothered looking at this style Bluetooth buds again. But it's a trip to a Nevada training center after the hottest july month on record in human history with averages around 110 in the area I'll be. I thought I'd take a chance on mild comfort. I'm hoping I didn't waste my money now that almost out of time.EDIT: It's been a few days so I'll add more input. Battery is pretty good, but it's not enough to bump a star.The app Skullcandy IQ is awful. It's what controls your key presses. The problem is the app is always on, but loses connection and resets all your programmed key presses. I end up having to reset them every day when they eventually connect poorly. The app logo constantly in my phones notification bar isn't necessary or tell me any input about my headphones. If it at least told me battery levels or connection status, maybe I wouldn't be so annoyed, but this just ISN'T ready for prime time.Also, the ear inserts are what caused the allergic reaction. They jerryrigged replacements I found by chance from a totally different set of wired buds from an old phone work well enough, but I shouldn't have to find my own replacements. At least having an option for different inserts that are non-reactive would be beneficial like memory foam or whatever. Again, Samsung Buds 2 had this EXACT issue and replacing inserts with an aftermarket set was the only solution. For a list of symptoms, it's pretty unmistakable: liquid discharge, discolored mucousal discharge in ear, weeping ear, flaking and scaly skim that seems to build up and shed, pain itching, inflammation, basically a large skin irritation in your ear canal that, if unmanaged, becomes a severe ear infection. Samsung got sued for it and has been paying out for their affected customers. Skullcandy is headed the same way with these unless they have a hypoallergenic replacement in the wing.If the connectivity issue wasn't so bad and not saving my preset remapped button setting wasn't so annoying, perhaps I would add a star or two, but this isn't ready for release and I'm probably returning after giving another day or two. Really sucks I'm screwed out of my trip for headphones, but I'm not gonna struggle with a new set of buds I paid good money for. I'll just go back to wired at this point.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 6, 2023

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Immediate issues
author: xjarius
content: I have long been a fan of Skullcandy headphones and earbuds, at least 10 - 15 years. The earbuds were always decent and sturdy, even if you got cheaper ones.My last pair of true wireless earbuds were the Skullcandy Indy earbuds, and I was so sorry to see these were no longer being made.But I was looking forward to the Rail ANC earbuds. First, ANC! Second, a decent IPX4. Third, great battery life. Plus, they cost more, so they must be higher quality, right? So I splurged a little on June 28, 2024. These earbuds sound pretty good. I can tell only a minor difference when the ANC is on and when it's off. The passthrough mode is okay, maybe about as good as the Indy's. The battery life was amazing. That's right. Was. We'll get to that. I loved using the app SkullIQ, where you can customize control settings. I was able to change what the number of taps on the sensor does. Super cool!My list of gripes as of 8/23/2024.First of all, how did my right earbud stop working within the first month? There's a sound when you press the sensor. Within 2 weeks, it started randomly making the sensor pressing sound. Then it started saying Pairing... pairing... as if I was doing long single presses. Then it started skipping to the next track(triple press) and trying to start Spotify* (double press). Within the first month it just wouldn't power on at all. I tried all the tricks and worked with Skullcandy support to no avail. They suggested I submit a warranty claim.*Sidenote: how does it fail to open Spotify whether I'm listening to Spotify or not?).Sometimes they will connect to my phone even thought they are in their case and should be off. My Indy's would do this, too, but it took at least a year or two before that started. This started within the first two months.Every once in a while they wont even connect and you will have to go to settings, forget device, then pair them to your phone again. This is what Skullcandy support had me try to fix the right earbud. Occasionally I need to do this on the left earbud as well. Well if you do this, you have to customize the SkullIQ app again.The case is cheap. My Indy's case was solid and sturdy. It had a few LEDs to indicate how much battery life was left in the case. This new one is flimsy with one light that shows you if the battery is being charged or not.Lastly, the Indy's stayed in my ears much better than the Rail's do. So I'm constantly needing to readjust them in my ears. With a name like Rail, I figured it was made for an active lifestyle. I wash windows for a living, but these things don't stay in my ears too well.As of today, they are in the mail headed to San Diego for the warranty claim. Hopefully, I get a somewhat better product when it's returned.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 23, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars These buds murder AirPods Pro 2
author: Joshua Busby
content: Tl;dr - Here‚Äôs what you probably came here to find out:- Sound quality is phenomenal. Deep bass and rich crystal clear highs. Hands down better than AirPods Pro 2, and significantly so imo.- Battery life is the longest I‚Äôve ever experienced, once again shaming Apple.- Noise cancelling is great. For this, I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs equal to AirPods Pro 2, if not slightly better.- They fit very snugly in my ears and don‚Äôt fall out with movement. They come with three pairs of ear tips, each a different size.- Very good construction and premium feel. They also look really good.- The charging case can either be charged with a type-C wire, or on any wireless charger by laying them down on the charging pad.- The Skullcandy IQ app is actually useful with features such as custom EQ, voice control configuration, ANC controls, etc.Long version:Borrowed my Wife‚Äôs AirPods Pro 2 off and on for a week before deciding to give these a go as they were 50% off, and as someone who listens to metal and hard rock, these things absolutely murder Apple‚Äôs flagship buds. As far as sound quality and loudness, going from the AirPods Pro 2 to these was like going from ramen noodles to premium ribeye. The bass is right where it should be, and the treble is crystal clear and clean. Loud is an understatement. I use Spotify Premium and am happy with the EQ within that app, but the EQ within the Skullcandy app is really great as well. These are made well and feel great. Battery is roughly 6-7 hours, so really great. They fit great, are very comfortable, and don‚Äôt fall out with movement. All in all, these buds are amazing. Apple can‚Äôt compete.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Unfortunately, not a great purchase‚Ä¶ but I am keeping them.
author: Kyle H.
content: I had skull candy headphones as a kid, and loved them. Granted, this is back when headphones still physically plugged into a device or phone. So when I saw these I was super excited. Unfortunately, they ended up being the LEAST enjoyable earbud I have purchased, yet. Before you read further, it is worth noting that a lot of people are super satisfied with these earbuds, so it is extremely likely that this is more about my user preferences not matching with the specs of the item. That being said, the following are the agitations and the positives I‚Äôve experienced since using them:THE CONS:‚Ä¢ The earbuds regularly don‚Äôt sync with my phone & I am prompted at least 3x a week to ‚Äúforget‚Äù the earbuds and then go through the pairing process again. Not a huge problem, but a mild inconvenience made worse by the regularity in which it happens.‚Ä¢ The earbuds fall out of my ears from my jaw moving, which happens often, because my jaw moves when I talk on the phone.‚Ä¢ The earbuds require an app to be downloaded to my phone, in order to customize each button sequence to the desired function (I.e. answer phone, play music, skip forward, etc.). The frustration I have with this is that the earbuds can answer a phone call with a tap, but they cannot end the call with a tap. So, in order to hang up, I have to use my phone screen (or wait for the person I‚Äôm talking with to hang up).‚Ä¢ The earbuds verbalize information about the device, each time you put them in your ear. I can see how some people might prefer this, but I prefer just a simple one or two note ‚Äúchime‚Äù to let me know the earbud is connected to the device. These earbuds state the following, each time I put them in: *chime*‚Ä¶ pause‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúBattery at __%‚Äù‚Ä¶ pause‚Ä¶ ‚Äúconnected‚Äù. This will happen, even if you‚Äôre listening to music or are actively talking on the phone & you swap earbuds. Again, not a huge problem, but a frequent nuisance.THE PROS:Now, despite these gripes, I will say that the sound quality of both phone calls and music are REALLY good (for the price of the earbud). Moreover, I have used AirPods, Beats Pro, and JBL earbuds‚Ä¶ and I have had a few people tell me that the sound quality of my voice for them (when on the phone) is noticeably better. I did not ask these people before hand, they voiced it on their own accord. One person even said ‚Äúdid you get new headphones?! I can hear you so much better now!‚Äù. For these reasons, despite my many personal gripes, I am keeping the headphones. But buyer beware, they are definitely frustrating at times.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Amazing sound quality, awkward fit
author: ThatGamingKid45
content: I purchased these in November 2023 and have been using them regularly for the past few months. The sound quality is amazing, I absolutely adore the ‚Äúpersonal sound‚Äù through the app it uses. It connects really easily, barely a hassle. I like the added features, like how it can connect to Spotify instantly and play from the earbuds, or how it can detect whether or not you‚Äôre listening to an audiobook/podcast and adjust volumes accordingly. I also like the noise cancelling, it has a slider where you can adjust how much or how little you‚Äôd want. Overall, when it comes to the sound, it knocks it out of the ballpark.Though, one of my only gripes with it is the fit. It wasn‚Äôt built for movement. Even walking around with it indoors, it tends to pop out unless I continually push it back in. I‚Äôve tried the multiple ear tips provided, but it doesn‚Äôt seem to help much. The other gripe I have with it is the controls, and how sensitive it is. Remember how I mentioned I have to continually push it back in? Well, 9/10 times I‚Äôll accidentally pause the song, skip, or start pairing mode. The touch controls are nice, but I wish it wasn‚Äôt as sensitive, because the slightest poke sends it into a frenzy.Overall, it‚Äôs amazing if you‚Äôre just using it at home, stationary. The sound and battery life is phenomenal. If you plan to use it on the go, walking to and from places, etc. I‚Äôd advise to go elsewhere.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Disappointing
author: Bandito
content: I am a big fan of the SC line of ear buds. Let's get that out of the way. I own a set of Grind and Push Active, currently, and the case for the Push stopped charging, which is why I am here.I had really high hopes for these and was really let down. I purchased a set (XT) from Walmart and they sounded terrible. I returned them and saw these on sale and got them, thinking they might be different. The Walmart set was tagged with the 'XT' qualifier, so I didn't know if there were different components used in them.There aren't.1. I feel like I have average sized hands for a dude, so I don't know why I seem to fumble with getting the buds out and into the case. And when I say fumble, I'm talking about the kind of fumble that causes them to fall down a storm drain 10 feet away. I have had to hunt them down because they shot across the room when getting them out. I don't do that with my other sets. I feel like its my technique, but I dont know what the right one is...2. Touch Sensitivity is off the charts. I cannot turn up the volume, turn on ANC or anything else without accidentally pausing what I am listening to, EVERY SINGLE TIME. If you want to take one out to talk to someone, don't hold it in your hand. Now my boss knows I listen to Hailee Steinfeld, and SkullCandy is to blame. 100%. Thanks... I stopped using this feature, I lost patience and went back to doing everything on my phone. This may be a "give it time" thing or maybe making pause/play three taps is the answer.3. The sound. It's kinda bad... especially when you get up in volume. Even at about 75% I can hear distortion and they're no louder than my other sets at 75%. This is why I returned the XT to Walmart, because of this distortion. I do not have this issue with the Grind or Push Active, even at 100%.I don't know what happened.The positives:1. The announcement is toned down and less obtrusive. So if someone calls and I want to put them in, I dont have to pause my convo for 45 seconds. I can hear over it enough now to understand what's being said.2. The bass on them is really f'in nice, which is what I wanted when I bought these. I think this is the trade-off with distortion though, which is a major bummer. I will say that when these things get rockin with a nice bass track that doesn't distort, they can wiggle themselves right out of your ear. All you have to do is push them back in...pause...

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Full-Bodied Sound ... For One
author: Josh Doncevic
content: Bought these during Amazon's Black Friday sale with the express purpose of listening to music at work. Up until today (3/5/2024), when this review is being written, ownership has been fantastic. The Rail ANC earbuds performed effortlessly and are light-years ahead of my previous earbuds from Gravastar. However, one earbud, the left specifically, has ceased to emit any sound. Its touch and ANC features still operate, but there is zero sound emitted through the speaker. This is the first time an earbud or similar device has done this in my experience, and while I know nothing is perfect forever, but I am wondering how it happened. I have my volume set to its lowest setting and do not drop, abuse, or otherwise mistreat the device. When not in use, both earbuds are stored in the charging case. I should also add that I did attempt to pair the earbuds as if for the first time and the left earbud still refused to emit any sound. A disappointment to an otherwise fantastic product.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great For The Price!
author: Jared Morgan
content: The Skullcandy RAIL's offer a mix of impressive features but still has a few limitations. The Bluetooth connectivity is exceptional, ensuring a seamless pairing process, stable connection, and quick reconnection. The device excels in battery performance, boasting extended life and rapid charging capabilities. However, it falls short for gaming enthusiasts due to noticeable latency issues, impacting the overall gaming experience. Additionally, it's worth noting that the Skullcandy RAIL's do not have in-ear detection. Despite these limitations, the Skullcandy RAIL remains a strong contender for those prioritizing top-notch audio in their daily activities. What makes it even more appealing is that it offers these features at a great value for the money.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars 9.5/10
author: Dylan
content: Very satisfied with the quality of these earbuds. The sound is fantastic, dynamic sound with satisfying bass. The active noise canceling works surprisingly well for in ear buds. Just the ANC alone with no audio will significantly reduce background noise. There is also an option for ambient noise to be played which i like to use when reading or sleeping.If you have the ANC on & are playing music you will not hear any background noise short of a jackhammer next to your ears.As to be expected from in ear buds, but still worth mentioning, there is virtually zero noise leak from these. People around you will not be able to hear what you're playing even if it's loud.I bought these mainly to use at the gym. One of my main concerns was that these would fall out easily while I'm workout out or running, as I've had that issue with other ear buds. I have not had that issue at all, these fit very securely in the ear and do not fall out easily at all, while still being very comfortable. There is a little ridge that will slide into the groove above your ear canal that makes them very secure.Battery life is great and they charge quickly. They come with a C-to-C charging cord that will charge the case very rapidly.My only minor complaint is that they don't go quite as loud as I would like them to, but I'm someone who always listens to my music very loudly. They are by no means quiet earbuds and this should only dissuade you if you're someone looking for earbuds capable of going extremely loud.Really for this price they are fantastic. Nothing I've purchased in this price range previously comes close.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States September 6, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars No Way
author: Dillon
content: Mother of GOD these are good.1) Super comfortable and secure. I can't even get them to fall out with the most ridiculous of abrupt head movements.2) Easy as hell to set up with my Samsung Galaxy phone. As soon as I opened the case, my phone woke up and was like, "Eeeey, these yours?" And I was off to the races.3) Feature rich as all getout. Disclaimer. I am not somebody that likes very feature rich things. I like my audio devices to play audio. Nothing more. These changed my mind completely. It works so seamlessly with the phone it feels like an expansion pack or something. Answering calls is easy and has incredible mic quality. Not sure how. Playing, pausing, and playing next and previous songs all uses one touch surface and it's way easier than expected.4) My absolute favorite thing about these. Audio quality. I'm absolutely blown away by how good these sound. I didn't think it was possible to get such huge sound out of earbuds. These lil things are the size of a roided out bean and they absolutely dominate my entire skull. Most people are going to be like "Yo the bass is fire. Riz and bruh and other sounds," but it's so much more than that. They deliver rich and clean audio across all frequencies. Yes, bass included. Very very f****** included. I listen to a lot of metal, which can be really demanding of speakers. The genre often includes a wide range of audio input simultaneously. These handle anything you throw at them no problem.In short, buy these. Go. Do it. Begone.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 10, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Absolutely Awesome
author: Tyrone Johnson
content: After only using over the ear headphones for years, I thought about it and thought about it because of concerns about sound quality and fit. After reading the reviews of these buds and more thought, I went ahead and order these. Received them a couple days ago and I'm blown away. Not only do they fit in my ears like a glove, but the sound quality is superb. Pairing them with my Samsung Ultra was quick, smooth and effortless. Rich sound with highs and lows that stand out. Very decent bass. Cannot hear anything going on around me. I had to mow my grass after I got them so I decided to use them to listen to music while mowing. I could not even hear the mower and had to take them out once or twice to make sure that the mower was running. The reasonable cost for such a great quality pair of ear buds (Samsung) at that is mind blowing. My wife tried them out and now she wants a pair for herself! Thank you Amazon, thank you Samsung!

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good buds!
author: David D
content: I recently purchased the SAMSUNG Galaxy Buds FE True Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds in the Graphite color and I have been extremely impressed with their performance. As someone who is always on the go and constantly listening to music or podcasts, having a reliable and comfortable pair of earbuds is essential for me. The Galaxy Buds FE have exceeded my expectations in both of these areas.First and foremost, the comfort and secure fit of these earbuds is top-notch. The wing-tip design ensures that they stay in place even during intense workouts or when I'm running errands. I have tried many other wireless earbuds in the past and have always struggled with finding a pair that stays in my ears comfortably. The Galaxy Buds FE have solved this problem for me and I can wear them for hours without any discomfort.The sound quality of these earbuds is also impressive. The audio is clear and crisp, with a good balance of bass and treble. I have used them for both music and phone calls and have been pleased with the sound in both scenarios. The touch controls on the earbuds are also very convenient and easy to use. I can easily pause or skip a song without having to take out my phone.One of the standout features of these earbuds is the auto switch audio. This allows me to seamlessly switch between my phone and laptop when I receive a call or want to listen to something on my computer. It's a small feature, but it has made a big difference in my daily routine.I also appreciate the built-in voice assistant feature. I can easily access my virtual assistant with just a touch of the earbud, making it convenient to make calls, send texts, or get directions without having to take out my phone.The battery life on these earbuds is also impressive. I can use them for several hours without needing to recharge, and the charging case provides additional battery life when I'm on the go. The case is also compact and easy to carry around.Overall, I highly recommend the SAMSUNG Galaxy Buds FE True Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds. They offer a comfortable and secure fit, great sound quality, and convenient features that make them a must-have for anyone looking for a reliable pair of wireless earbuds. Whether you're a music lover, fitness enthusiast, or just someone who wants a hassle-free listening experience, these earbuds are definitely worth considering.The only drawback is that the case is not wireless charging. Losing the one star.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States April 11, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars The Perfect Storm!!! Flawless execution of what SHOULD BE
author: TheChrisSimon
content: 2 years ago I was I acquired a pair of the Galaxy Buds+. I would have never I have purchased them myself, as spending top dollar for a pair of earbuds or headphones to me was not something that I would have spit my money on. I had no instructions, just a little black case in the bottom of a drawer, that someone had left behind. What I discovered, was a piece of technology, that made my life better, and it's quality, simplicity, and joy that it bestowed upon my soul.I only had that unit for a period of maybe 2 months. During that time I use them to live. The full sound l, flawless amplification of surrounding noises, everything about these was amazing. The fit in my ear, the simplicity of touch controls, everything made them something I didn't know that I couldn't live without. Through sheer negligence, I I dropped the right bud into a toilet, and flust it before I realized what had happened. There was a period of grief. And that left bud sat in its case and a drawer for 4 months, as I did not have the disposable funds to go buy a new pair, until it occurred to me to just buy a replacement for the lost bud. Purchase of the second hand market I could never get it to pair and it just sent me further into sadness.Set that time I have made an emission, define a worthy replacement. I have spent conservatively $1,800 and tried every brand from generic to Apple to the Samsung's themselves come and nothing matched the pure perfection of the plus. Well what are you going to do they don't make them anymore. And then on prime I saw that Samsung was selling them, for more then they're top of the line current model. How's this possible? They quit selling them years ago?My theory is that the human ear, Is only so big. There was a team at Samsung that put this bud into the Universe, and those in the upper echelon know it is the Alpha qnd Omaga. I planned up the lessons, and the perfect bargain earbud does not make for the quarterly Prophets jump where the marketing team happy. So they have hidden this, for those that are only in the know. Hey now you know, I bought and Amazon refurbished pair, as well as the buds FE. As a birthday present. The buds FE arrived 3 days before the plus, and I did not unseal the package, because I knew in my heart. I went to my Amazon locker 3 days later with speed and haste that not felts in years. Went home and let them sit for a good I don't know hour and a half as I twittered about my apartment. And when I put them in my ear? Yeah, that's the stuff. Look no further. I mean wait I don't want you to take them all, keep your secret between us. Don't tell anybody about me, we will be the ones the know.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Hard to beat, but get aftermarket tips!
author: Thunderlizard
content: For the money, these buds are fantastic! Call qaulity inbound and out is good, with teh exception of an occasional improper insert in my ear making my voice sound like a walkie-talkie...simple repositioning fixes this.I noticed ambiant sound blockage was not that great with the stock eartip, but I purchased an aftermarket set of tips that has a multilayer construction (Diofit Premium) for next to nothing and they now block almost all but the harshest outside sound. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Samsung can do better.
author: JohnnyD
content: Overall, these earbuds sound great, the noise cancelation works very well, they last a long time while listening to music and they fit perfectly.So why the 4 star rating? First you get a white charging case with black headphones inside. There is NO other option, its how all Galaxy Buds FE come. That's silly, and shows just how badly Samsung is trying to penny pinch. I purchased them in black because both my Samsung phones, watch and other accessories are in black. If I had wanted white, then I would have bought the white earbuds!Secondly, unlike the other Galaxy Bud models currently. there is no wireless charging available. While that's not a major issue for me, it would sometimes be convenient to just be able to set the whole case down on my Samsung trio wireless charging stand. Instead I have to set them off to the side and attach the USB-C cable to the back. Again NBD , but it's annoying that I don't even have the option to do it.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Incredible Value, Samsung Delivers
author: Matt
content: Sound Quality: 8/10These don‚Äôt sound like earbuds I just dropped $75 on. They sound like premium quality, well-balanced, and capable wireless earbuds. Bass actually comes through with a satisfying low end and instrument separation is clear and natural. They‚Äôre also handle dialogue clarity very well.Comfort and Fit: 9/10These are the most comfortable wireless earbuds I‚Äôve ever used. They feel nearly weightless, but at the same time very secure. The rubberized winged edge on each earbud hooks right into your ear without being uncomfortable over 4+ hours of use.Case Quality: 8/10The reason I needed to buy a pair of wireless earbuds is because the case for my last pair came apart at the hinge after a few drops. I‚Äôm not always easy on these things, they get tossed into backpacks and I‚Äôm bound to drop them here and there. The case for these feels pretty sturdy and secure. They‚Äôre a hard, glossy plastic and there‚Äôs a mechanism in place holding the lid up when fully open, which is satisfying. I don‚Äôt like how easily I can bend the lid backward as it seems to have quite a bit of give to it, but when closed it feels firmly clasped shut, so hopefully that‚Äôs never something I need to worry about.Battery Life: 7/10I get a solid 5+ hours of listening time out of these with noise cancelling on, and 3+ charges out of the case. They‚Äôre not going to blow your mind, but they hold their own just fine.Noise Cancelling: 8/10Really surprised at how well these block out noise for a pair of earbuds that cost less than $100. Cutting grass or walking near noisy roads won‚Äôt be an issue.I want acknowledge a big reason you may not want to buy these. If you‚Äôre an iPhone user, there is no app available to adjust EQ or add the functionality to skip or reverse - only pause, play, and noise cancelling controls as a default will be available to you. If you have a windows laptop or could use somebody else‚Äôs Android device for a few minutes, you can enable the ability to skip and reverse and play around with some other features. I myself use iPhone but don‚Äôt mind lack of app support because my fiancee has an Android, and once you set them up you‚Äôre not likely to need the app very often, if at all.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Better to buy new and Best with Samsung phone
author: Julie
content: This is a bit long but I feel it provides good info regarding your phone or electronic device to be paired with earbuds and purchasing new vs used earbuds. If you have questions about these topics please read!I purchased these for my boyfriend. He has a Samsung S22. I have bought him multiple types of brand new earbuds in the $70-$80 range in the past. He had to charge all those daily in order to used for 1.5 hrs while he walked. I wanted to buy him something nicer so I bought these. I chose to buy a used set in hopes that they were in great condition and maybe the box was just torn. I changed them overnight on accident (I prefer not to charge too long). Then paired then with my iPhone. I have owned several versions and pairs of iPods and Beats Pro (over the ear). So my first reaction was disappointment because the sound quality did not compare and little things didn‚Äôt work the same. For example when you take your Beats out if your ear whatever your watching stops. That is not the case with these. Also when a call comes in, I had to manually change the option to the ear bud on my phone screen vs just answering by touching my ear. However, I still gave them to my boyfriend for Easter and when he paired them with his galaxy he was prompted to add an extra app that gave him different features than I had with my Apple. Initially he was not too impressed with the sound, he expected them to be louder. The noise canceling was so good, he had to take them out to hear me talk to him. What he loved about them was the length of time he was able to go before charging the case. Remember I charged them one time, then he used them off of my original charge after sitting in the box for a few days. He wore them everyday for 5 days without charging the case. At that point he was really happy with them. Enough to overlook the sound quality since it was not what he expected. Unfortunately when he charged the case he was not able to get the Right earbud to charge. We tried different troubleshooting methods. Unfortunately none of them have worked. We will be sending them back. I don‚Äôt have experience using Apple headphones or buds with Samsung phones but I feel if I had bought these brand new, he would keep them vs buying headphones like mine. I‚Äôd rather pay an extra $50 to get new products going forward. Please air on the side of caution if you buy used or refurbished version of these ear buds. Hopefully this helps someone trying to decide between new or used and Apple/Beats products vs Other earbuds to pair with an android phone.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Not overly impressed
author: Amazon Cutstomer
content: I've only had these a day but there are not many reviews so I'll give my 1st impressions. I wore them for a few hours doing yard work (using my Samsung S22) and tried them with some of my favorite test tracks connected to my PC and using Amazon HD music (using Exclusive mode)The first thing that surprised me was the white case... I ordered black, and at first thought they sent the wrong ones but opened the case and the buds themselves were black. I don't like white, but whatever.Looking at the case there is not much indication of what is the front and it's a bit fiddly to open. The magnet to suck the buds into place is not very strong, so a bit fiddly to lay them in the case.I don't like wearing buds much, but these were pretty comfortable right out of the box. The insertion was not quite as deep as I like but they stayed in well while I was moving around and I did not feel the need to keep adjusting them.How do they sound:I want to emphasize these are first impressions.These have a polite sound that would probably please many people. I'm not one of them. When I got the Lypertek buds for the same price I told people "I can't believe how good a sound you can get for $100 these days". With these, I would say "They are ok, most people would like them".They are "fine" for having something playing in your ear while you do something else but they did not bring out any joy in the music for me. Nothing stood out about the sound. Ordinary comes to mind or, nothing wrong but nothing right. I'm not into 'soundstage' the the lack of one while listening to live tracks actually stood out to me.The sound is a bit congested, the instruments kind of bunched into each other. There is no 'air' around the instruments. I found myself pushing the volume louder than I normally listen to "wake them up a bit".Detail retrieval is decent, but you are not going to notice the reverb, the grind of a distorted guitar, the 'ting' of the drumsticks on a cymbal, breath sounds, etc. The overall presentation is smooth enough from low to high, with no glaring holes, or peaks. If I had to fault the frequency response it would be male voices. Just a bit in your face at times. Bass get a bit tubby if you try to push it much. In "normal" mode I found it just about right.Let's see what I can 'fix' with EQ. The EQ in the App has 9 bands, cool! But that hardly matters if there is no custom EQ option. Seriously Samsung? The Sennheiser App only has 3 bands but at least they let you set a custom EQ, name it, and save it.There are 7 presets, but none of them really gave me something I liked. But there is enough variety that most people would find something they like.I'm mixed on keeping them. The sound is good enough for what I want them for. listening to music while I do something else. They are comfortable and stay in well, but I am not impressed with the sound. It's "fine", it's "okay", and "good enough" but not impressed with the sound for the $100 price point.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States October 21, 2023

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Compared to 4 other Earbuds...
author: Connor
content: I bought these earbuds along with 4 other pairs, with the intent of comparing them over a couple weeks and returning all but my favorite. Here were the results:Beats Fit Pro - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B09JL65GNM?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_detailsPros ‚Äì These buds had some great base, and the wingtip gave them a fit that made them refuse to fall out of my ears. But the best feature? Physical ‚Äúclicky‚Äù buttons on each one of the buds. You press in and hear/feel the click, rather than relying on a touchscreen-like feature. No need to guess if you tapped them once or twice, you will know.Cons ‚Äì The wingtip gives a very sturdy fit, but not the most comfortable. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend to anyone with smaller ears. The noise canceling was solid, but nothing special. And this may be picky, but I didn‚Äôt care for most of the color schemes available. I prefer my earbuds to be hard to notice, and even the black ones have a bright red letter ‚Äúb‚Äù in the middle.Beats Studio Buds - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B096SV8SJG?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_detailsPros ‚Äì Very comfortable with the same great physically ‚Äúclicky‚Äù buttons as the Beats Fit Pro. Noise canceling seemed slightly better than average. Great base. Classic look.Cons ‚Äì Tested during a workout, a little bit of sweat had these sliding right out of my ear. The case for these earbuds also was the flimsiest of any I had tested, with a very weak hinge that I was scared of breaking off within the 2 weeks of using.Samsung Galaxy Buds Pro - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08MWZHHKP?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_detailsPros ‚Äì A neat feature that I noticed only in these earbuds was that it had noise amplification as well as noise cancelation. With one swipe in the app, the surrounding sound was actually louder and clearer than it would be without the earbuds in. Great if you are hard of hearing, or just enjoy snooping on conversations out of reach.Cons ‚Äì Similar to the Beats Studio Buds, these didn‚Äôt stay in during a workout. They were usable, but every 10 minutes I found myself pushing them back into my ear. And this is an opinion, but these are the ugliest earbuds out of the bunch. The shiny black gleam made it look like a large beetle was hanging out in my ear. No visible brand placement either, which makes them appear cheap and generic rather than the quality Samsung they are.Samsung Galaxy Buds Live - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B09TBM1L3S?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_detailsPros ‚Äì Cost effective! I added these to the test group because of the unique shape, and for that they are worth giving a try. If you have small ears and do not like the rubber insert that is standard in most other earbuds, these may be perfect for you.Cons ‚Äì Poor fit for large ears. These were tested the least of all of the buds, because the fit was so bad for my ear shape that they wouldn‚Äôt stay in if I turned my head too fast.Bose QuietComfort - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08C4KWM9T?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_detailsPros ‚Äì Bose noise canceling is unmatched. If your primary use for earbuds is to cancel out that background white noise, this is the pair for you. The sound quality is great, not too heavy on the base. The case for the earbuds stood out from the rest as the only one that impressed me. Felt very study, and I had no worries tossing it into a gym bag or cup holder. The only case with a button latch to make sure it doesn‚Äôt open accidentally.Cons ‚Äì This was the most expensive pair of earbuds by a longshot, and there were still some things I felt could be improved. The rubber inserts had more of a ‚Äúflayed‚Äù shape rather than the ‚Äúrounded‚Äù shape that is standard. My guess is that this was by design, because the earbuds were also slightly heavier than others and may need that extra in-ear grip. The flayed shape did make them sturdier, but at the cost of them being uncomfortable in an active situation. They were also the largest earbuds, and stuck out from the side of my head further than I would have liked.My favorite? The beats fit pro! While I wouldn‚Äôt recommend this pair for everyone, it was perfect for my routine. My music taste benefits from the boosted base, and the wingtip shape was perfect for any workouts. The feature that really convinced me was the physical buttons, something that I didn‚Äôt realize how desperately I needed.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 11, 2022

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Initial review and comparison to other brands
author: philip seitz
content: I love these earbuds. They feel definitely worth the price and a all around great buy. Giving me exactly what I was looking for.For years I have used the raycon E55 and some of the features I loved about raycon was the manual button in the earbuds, excessive bass and great inside-ear fit.Recently however, raycon has gone the way of the world‚Äî they have put sensors on the earbuds in the place of buttons and Balanced out the audio. So I began my search for new earbuds.‚ÄîTHE SOUND‚ÄîBoth the AirPods, galaxybuds and raycons I have tried tend to be balanced and prioritize giving equal notes to all instruments For a clear and concise sound, But to someone who is not an audiophile it sounds very flat and devoid of the punch that I desire. For me- I want it to be great sounding but also noticeably bass heavy. These Beats Studio buds deliver. The company recognizes that your not using these to analyze a song. These are for the people who like bass and want to feel some gravitas in their ears!‚ÄîCONNECTIVITY‚ÄîThese connect effortlessly to iPhone, as if they were AirPods. It was the single biggest factor that blew me away with these. They are incredibly easy to connect. I cannot speak for android but these work great. They do not have a lot of audio adjustments like Bose but I frankly don‚Äôt need them to. You can easily see the battery state on both buds and the case from a pop up window in your apple home screen whenever opening the case, just like AirPods.‚ÄîFIT‚ÄîThe fit is not as good as the raycon E55 but only by a little bit. They fit snuggly in your ears well enough that they do not fall off when running and working out. Although adjustments might need to be made to them occasionally. (I have small ears, so the fit is review as such)‚ÄîTHE CONTROLS‚ÄîThe controls are simple and straightforward. They are just like what you come to expect from earbuds. Single tap, double tap, triple tap.The earbuds HAVE AN ACTUAL BUTTON‚Ä¶ which I thought was extinct, I personally hate the sensor buttons because adjusting your earbuds in your ears would trigger the controls.While these do have a very sensitive physical button‚Äî it is easy to avoid while adjusting with practice.‚ÄîBATTERY‚ÄîThe battery lasts me all day, what more do you want?‚ÄîRANGE‚ÄîVery good, about 30+ feet‚ÄîCONS‚Äî-no MagSafe compatible charging-fit isn‚Äôt as perfect as some brands but is really good-if your an audiophile these earbuds are not balancedFinal call-If you like bass, and hate the sensor controls on most earbuds‚Äî these very well could be the best earbuds you could get. These are on par with earbuds in the 200$ range. And if your anything like me, you will love them! And if not, they might still be worth it to you‚ÄîUPDATE‚Äîthey have a hard time staying in when working out, and so I had to buy wing tips for these. They automatically have active noise cancellation on when you take them out of the case‚Ä¶ which I personally hate.And the cases battery is pretty short lived‚Ä¶ only lasts two days generally

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Quality sound and build, BUT...
author: Everest
content: After using these for a couple weeks straight, I think it's time to review.I would like to state upfront that I bought these on sale for $75. I bought the black ones because the pink ones weren't on sale.Let's start with some pros:The sound is very good, just about on par with my IEMs. These are definitely catered towards more bassy genres, but in the case of metal, I like being able to hear bass along side lead, and provides some heavy kicks. The physical button instead of just touch is an odd choice, but it works. The package comes with a free trial of Apple music (which I will never use), as well as a tiny usb-c to usb-c charger (so hopefully you have a spare usb-c block), and 3 different sized tips, small, meduim, and large. These have awareness mode, as well as a noise isolation mode. Awareness mode is nice, but noise isolation causes me to have a headache.Now some cons:This may be just my ears, but the small tip is too small, and the medium is just big enough to still be pushed out. The body is very smooth, and if you're someone that produces a lot of earwax (like me), it won't stay put and the only thing keeping it in is the tips, meaning you have to keep pushing them back in, and bumping the button. These sit in a very specific position, but don't really like to stay there. Because of the sound mostly being catered towards bass, some leads and vocals can sound a bit muddy at times. By default, the case doesn't have a loop for a string to hold on to and the case is very smooth, so you have to buy a third party case and put it over the stock case just to make it easier to hold on to. These come with an app, and it's very lackluster. No equalizer, there's a find earbuds feature but I'm pretty sure it's not GPS, and you can't mess with settings if the earbuds aren't connected, not to mention: why do my earbuds need to update?!In conclusion: these are good earbuds and I recommend them, but ONLY IF THEY'RE ON SALE.These are 100% worth the $75 I spent on them, but NO WAY ARE THEY WORTH THE $150 RETAIL PRICE TAG.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars actually disappointing
author: kimmy
content: bought these after my airpod pros died on me suddenly. i have been using these beats studio buds for about 6 months and the experience has been inconsistent to say the least. first issue: they fall out of my ears if i do simple things like turn my head or chew. i can barely walk or exercise with them in because they just fall out. i looked online and it seems others have had these issues; people were suggesting swapping the size of the actual ear bud and even wearing them in reverse (with the left bud in the right ear and right bud in left ear). neither if these worked for me. really made me appreciate the airpod design.it was fairly easy to connect the very first time but every time after that is almost always a pain. if the case is dead but the beats themselves are still charged it‚Äôs like it doesn't recognize that the beats are still working and refuses to connect. even if the case is charged sometimes it just will not recognize that the beats are in range of my phone, even if they're sitting right on top of each other. if it‚Äôs not straight up refusing to connect it‚Äôs disconnecting randomly. if i open my car door - even with the car turned off - the beats automatically disconnect from my phone as if it expects me to connect my phone to carplay. there are many times i have been talking on the phone using my beats and suddenly they will disconnect.the controls only kind of work. you can use the default preset controls like pressing twice for skipping songs and once for hanging up calls and the like. however you're supposed to be able to customize these controls to in your phone settings but they only work as long as the beats are disconnected. as soon as you put the beats away and disconnect everything goes back to default settings the next time you reconnect. noise cancellation is a joke, it sounds the same as when its on transparent mode or off.the case feels like cheap plastic. i got a silicone case because i was afraid of scratching it up. not much else to say about it.the color of the beats are great. i got red and it looks super cool. i think the sound quality is on par with my old airpod pros. when i am on the phone others have not had a problem with not hearing me or me coming across muffled, so that‚Äôs a plus.overall, these earbuds are nothing special. i got these around the holidays when they were almost half off. glad i didn‚Äôt pay full price for these as they are disappointing at best.ETA: as of july 2024 i ditched these and bought another pair of airpod pros. literally no regrets.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Gets it done
author: uhgar
content: The Beats Studio Buds are true wireless noise-cancelling earbuds that cater to a broad audience, including both Apple and Android users. Here's an unbiased review based on their design, sound quality, features, and value.Design and Comfort:The Beats Studio Buds have a compact and sleek design that makes them visually appealing and easy to carry. They come with three sizes of ear tips, allowing users to find a comfortable and secure fit. The earbuds are lightweight, which contributes to long-lasting comfort, making them suitable for extended use, whether for commuting, working out, or listening to music at home.Sound Quality:The sound profile of the Beats Studio Buds is bass-heavy, which is characteristic of Beats products. This makes them well-suited for genres like hip-hop, pop, and electronic music. However, some users may find that the emphasis on bass comes at the expense of mid-range clarity and treble detail. For audiophiles or those who prefer a more balanced sound, this might be a downside. Overall, the sound is energetic and immersive, which will appeal to many listeners, especially those who enjoy bass-forward audio.Noise Cancellation and Transparency Mode:The active noise cancellation (ANC) feature in the Beats Studio Buds is effective at reducing ambient noise, particularly low-frequency sounds like the hum of an airplane or office chatter. While the ANC is good for the price, it may not be as strong as that found in higher-end models like the AirPods Pro or Sony WF-1000XM4. The transparency mode, which allows ambient sound to filter through, works well for staying aware of your surroundings, making it a practical feature for outdoor use.Battery Life:The battery life of the Beats Studio Buds is decent, offering up to 5 hours of playback with ANC on (8 hours with ANC off), and up to 15 additional hours from the charging case. While this is sufficient for most daily uses, some competing models offer longer battery life. The case itself is compact and easy to pocket, though it lacks wireless charging, which might be a downside for some users.Connectivity and Features:One of the standout features of the Beats Studio Buds is their compatibility with both Apple and Android devices, providing a seamless experience across both platforms. They support one-touch pairing, have a built-in voice assistant, and offer IPX4 water resistance, making them sweat and splash-proof. However, they lack some advanced features found in other earbuds, such as in-ear detection and customizable EQ settings.Value for Money:The Beats Studio Buds are priced competitively, offering good value for those looking for true wireless earbuds with active noise cancellation. They are a great option for users who prioritize style, brand recognition, and bass-heavy sound. However, if you‚Äôre looking for the absolute best ANC or the most balanced sound profile, there are other options in the market that might better suit your needs.Conclusion:The Beats Studio Buds are a solid choice for those who enjoy bass-centric audio and need a reliable pair of true wireless earbuds with noise cancellation. They are particularly appealing to users who value design and brand, as well as those who want a product that works well across both Apple and Android ecosystems. While they may not have all the bells and whistles of higher-end models, they offer a good balance of performance and price, making them a worthy contender in the mid-range earbud market.
